EXAMINATIONS IN THE CELESTIAL
KINGDOM.
BOUT 600 A. D. a Chinese emperor instiAtuted
the first known competitive examina-

•

tions. They were in literary and historical
subjects, and the degrees given enabled their
possesors to enter the civil service. As a result,
to-day the great body of educated men in the
most immense nation on earth are pursuing
classical studies, which lead toward degrees
corresponding to our A. B., Ph. D., etc., conferring the right to go into politics; and these
degrees are obtained by undergoing a course of
tests before which the most fearsome college
examinations seem child's-play.
These great systems of government examinations for literary degrees are most important
to every educated Chinaman. For the degrees
are the only passports to public office; and to
get into politics is the earnest aim and hope of
every literary Chinaman.
This is quite
natural. From an Oriental's point of view,
government positions are most valuable, both
socially and financially. An imperial representative, in any of the nine ranks, enjoys
personal immunity, and belongs to the only
aristocracy of the land, that of education.
Moreover, the tremendous network of provincial government affords unexcelled opportunities for bribery and extortion. It is the
popular opinion that officers of the government
generally squeeze out of their positions about
ten times the lawful salary. Under these
attractive conditions, it is small wonder that
candidates flock by thousands to the towns
where the trials are conducted.

No. 15.

It is not known how many of the applicants
have attended the colleges and high schools.
A large number of them are prepared by tutors.
For all the test is alike; even the National
College at Pekin, the highest institution of
the empire, confers no privileges on its
graduates.
Four successive degrees may be won. The
first signifies "flowering talent," and has been
translated "bachelor of arts." It is conferred
at the provincial capitals. Each province of
the empire is divided into departments, and
these are subdivided into districts. A triple
series of examinations is held; the best men in
each district go up to the chief town of the
department, and the best men in each department proceed to the capital of the province.
To these finals not more than one-tenth of the
first applicants succeed. In 1832, 4000 men
came up for the first trial from twc: districts
aggregating 1,500,000 population. Out of
these 4000 only thirteen in one district, and
fourteen in the other, passed the first series.
A "bachelor" can be a great man in his
native town. He is enrolled among the "gentry," and his social position is assured. He is
exempt from corporal punishment. He can
be a magistrate, or the head man of the village.
And if he wishes to go on, he is eligible for
the next examination.
The second degree, that of "promoted men,"
is bestowed triennially at the 18 provincial
capitals. The examinations are very useful
in weeding out the bachelors and separating
them into "students" and "officers," since
bachelors' degrees are sometimes procured by
bribery and influence.

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The examining hall at Canton will serve as
a specimen. It contains 7500 cells, furnished
simply with two boards, one for sitting, the
other for writing. These cells are arranged
around a number of open courts, so that constant watch may be kept over the students.
This is no idle form. Miniature editions of
the classics and MS. essays are quite often
secreted by the applicants, in spite of the most
careful searching, which extends to each man's
wadded clothes and inkstand, or round lump
of sulphate of iron.
Penalties for this method of cheating the
professor are grotesquely severe, including the
punishment of the offender's father and tutor.
Among the Chinese, indeed, there is absolutely no idea of the "honor system." A
candidate who is caught breaking the rules is
expelled from the examinations, and his name
is "pasted out" on the main door; yet he turns
up again for the next trials with apparently
unimpaired standing.
The students, shut up in these tiny cells,
receive on the first day essay themes from the
Four Chinese Books, on the second day subjects from the Five Classics, and on the last
day
. topics concerning doubtful points of government. The first of these Five Classics
dates back to 1150 B. C. The Four Books are
comparatively modern. They were edited
about moo A. D. These ancient books of
wisdom are the mainstay of all Chinese literature and government. They contain innumerable philosophic sayings, thousands of which
each student must know by heart. For in
this, as in all other examinations, the best man
is he who can write from memory the greatest
number of Confucian maxims, who can most
closely imitate the terse style of the sages, and
who can turn out the largest quantity of polished verse in a given time.
The mental exercise of handling about thirteen such essay themes in three days' time can
be well appreciated by any college Senior.
The Chinese students, moreover, are bothered
by the smoke of the cooking around them,
enervated by the excessive September heat,
cramped and numbed by the long confinement

in their narrow cells, measuring 3x4 feet, in
which there is no room to lie down. They
often become insane; many of them die outright. Especially is this the case with the old
men who flunk year after year, but keep trying.
In sonic instances, father, son, and grandson
have been taking the same examination at the
same time. When an old gray-head succumbs
to the awful strain, his body is shoved through
a hole in the wall, left to the pity of his
friends.
Different is the reception that awaits the
victors—those who live and succeed. There
are sonic 70 or 8o of them, out of 5,000 to
o,000 applicants, in each province. They are
banqueted with great pomp by the governors,
commissioners and high officials; their names
are posted in a public place, while the governor bows, and salutes are fired. Offices are
open to those who wish them. The others are
ready to take the next examination.
The board of examiners, meanwhile, are
having their own troubles. There are ten
men; they are allowed twenty-five days for
their work, and they have to select the 70 or
8o best out of from 50,000 to 75,000 papers on
a dozen subjects. This might average about
260 essays a day for each examiner. The
marking system, too, is closely watched by
the students ; any impartiality or error is
liable to raise a storm of protest, and the examiners must steer carefully to avoid irritating
the graduates. The utmost rigidity, however,
is customary in marking the papers. One
abbreviation of a character has condemned an
essay.
Those "promoted men" who do not at once
take office may try for the third, or "doctor's"
degree. The examinations are held triennially
at Pekin. Each test lets through from 150 to
400 "doctors." The three honor men receive rewards from the Emperor himself; and
offices of all kind, civil and literary, are ready
for those who have passed the third degree.
The fourth and highest distinction is more
an office than a degree; for those who attain
it become members of the Imperial Academy,
and receive salaries. The examination is at

:.:••11111

THE NEWS-LETTER.
the Emperor's palace, before the greatest personages of the empire; and the degree is one
of the highest honors that can be bestowed
upon a Chinaman.
In this manner, beginning with an examination in the little district village, and finally
mounting to the court of the Son of Heaven
himself, a Chinaman of literary ability can
hold the most splendid offices and ranks in the
empire. The system has its faults: it allows
cheating, bribery, impersonations, the forging
of diplomas. But it consistently hammers at
the theory that the man must be fit for the
office. In this respect the Chinese system of
examinations has no parallel in any past or
present government.

A LIKENESS OF PROFESSOR FRANCIS
J. CHILD.
many days ago a medallion likeness of
NOT
Professor Francis J. Child, of Harvard
University, was presented to the Johns Hopkins University by Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
Professor in the Medical School. The likeness
is in bronze, and was modelled by Miss Lelia
M. Usher, of Boston. It is an excellent work
and brings vividly to mind the characteristics
of the man whom it portrays.
The advanced students of English, with
some of the instructors and a few friends,
assembled to review the life of Professor Child
and to bring to mind his various contributions
to the study of English literature and philology.
Three papers were presented by members of
the English Seminary, namely: by R. D. Miller, on the "Life and Character of Professor
Child;" by George D. Brown, on "Professor
Childs Investigations of Chaucer's L a n guage;" by L. Wardlaw Miles, on "Professor
Child's Studies of English and Scottish Ballads."
Professor Green, who had been a pupil of
Professor Child, also gave some personal reminiscences, and other speakers who were present contributed.to the interest of the occasion
by brief remarks.
It is not generally known that at the open-

3

ing of this University Professor Child was
invited to come here as Professor of English.
He was strongly tempted to accept, but certain
changes were made in his relations to Harvard
which lessened his duties there, and he at
length declined the overtures from Baltimore.
Some passages of his letter are still of interest:
"As I told you, a large salary is a consideration that my circumstances will not allow me
to make light of. The liberal plan of your
University presents attractions which are at
least equal to the better salary. You see,
therefore, that I do not find it easy to decline
the honor which you offer me. If you will
take off one half my years and the obligations
to other people which I have incurred in them,'
I will accept your proposition with delight."
When it was found that he could not come
as a permanent professor, he was invited to
come as a lecturer, and this he did for two
successive years. In the first year he lectured
upon Chaucer; in the second, upon "Ballads;"
and he gave a supplementary course of lectures
upon Shakespeare.

AFTER
lacrosse team has met with defeat, but a
defeat of which we have no cause to be
ashamed. Naturally it is a disappointment, a
bitter disappointment, to every son of "old
Tommy Hopkins" to witness such a finale
after the most brilliant lacrosse season we have
ever had, but no fault can be found with our
men for the result. They did their best; no
more could be asked. Swathmore played a
better game, and—won. Starting the season
with men such as McInnes and Maddren out
of the game, the Hopkins lacrosse team
showed how machine-like team work could
be developed, and the result was an attack
which, taken as a unit, has never been surpassed, if equalled here.
Three of the hardest games of the season
within eight days, was a fearful strain on our
men ; but, after it is over, it is useless to speculate upon what the results might have been
if circumstances had been different. "The

Lord loveth whom he chasteneth;" so, after
all, the lesson may not be altogether devoid of
beneficial results. At all events we have a
team to be proud of, and Captain Tyler and
his men are to be congratulated for their season's work.

OW that the Hullabaloo elections are over,
and an editorial staff representative of the
class of 1902 has been chosen to edit next
year's book, it is only fair to say that while
these men will doubtless exert every effort to
make their publication a success, a great deal
of this success depends upon the rest of the
class. It must be borne in mind that the
Hullabaloo is not a creation of some dozen men
who have been honored by being chosen to
edit it, but a product of the entire class. Remember, every Junior is an integral part of
the class of 1902, and next year's Hullabaloo
is the official publication of that class, in which
every member should feel a vital interest.
This interest will be made much stronger by a
contribution of your talent to the book. Bear
this in mind during the coming vacation, and
devote some of your spare moments to writing
something for your class book. During the
next scholastic year, be on the alert for interesting items that will help to swell its pages.
If the interest of each member of the class can
be sufficiently aroused for them to take this
small amount of trouble, THE NEWS-LETTER
predicts that next year's Hullabaloo will be the
best ever published at the University.

COLUMBIA, 1.

Saturday, May 4th, Captain Tyler's men
ONscored
another victory and added to their
belts the scalps of the men from Columbia.
Both teams played a very creditable game, and
the New Yorkers were beaten only by the
superior team work and faster stick work of
the Hopkins men. Owing to a severe injury
to his foot, Putts was unable to play at his
usual position, which was filled by StrausStraus has always played on the defense,
where his wonderful coolness stands him in
good stead; but he did well in his new position
and put up a clean heady game.
For the most part, the work was done by
the attack, which put up a fair game, although
the passing at times was very ragged; and only
once did the defense have half a show, and that
at the time when the visitors scored their only
point.
The stars of the game were Hatch and
Bandel. Hatch's playing was steady and
thoroughly reliable. He accepted every opportunity and shot three of the seven goals;
Bandel also distinguished himself by shooting
three goals from a very difficult position.
Sayler signaled his return to the game by
clever work at third defense.
Both teams started off with a rush. After
the face-off Straus got the ball and tried for a
goal, but failed. Hatch then got the ball and
shot for the post. It looked like a goal, but
proved not to be, and the ball was soon down
the field again. On his next attempt Hatch
was more successful and scored the first point
for Hopkins. Columbia was the next to score.
Bigelow got the ball and passed to Stewart.
Stewart tipped to Major who placed the ball in
the net. From this time on the Hopkins
attack bombarded their opponent's goal, which
in the end netted them seven points.
The defense did the best work for the Blue
and White. Lindsay, the goal tend, was
applauded warmly, and the work of O'Dwyer,

Colwell and Schwerin in their struggle to keep
the ball out of the net was notable. The body
checking of the New Yorkers was frequent
and well done.

HARVARD, 0.

ON Monday, May 6th, the best game of
lacrosse seen here this season resulted in a
victory of our boys over the visitors from
"fair Harvard" by a score of 4 too. Up to
her defeat here, the record of the Crimson has
been a brilliant one, and the success of the
Hopkins men in white-washing them was a
most gratifying surprise. Both teams put up
an excellent game, and the representatives of
the Black and Blue fairly outdid themselves.
In all points Hopkins outclassed Harvard, and
her success is well merited. Hopkins' team
work was splendid, and time after time the ball
came rapidly up the field. Each man on the
attack tipped with such a precision as to cause
the crowd to stand in open-mouthed astonishment.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
Inside of two minutes after the referee's
whistle sounded the first goals had been scored
by our boys, and before another two minutes
passed a second tally was added. Much of the
credit for this fast scoring is due to the
Hopkins coaches and Captain. Tyler. After a
most careful study of the past games with
Harvard it was decided that Hopkins must
"get in the game" from the start. So they
did, and the two goals were the reward of this
timely advice. Before the half had ended the

one of the greatest games of lacrosse ever

by Hopkins men, Swarthmore defeated the home team on last Saturday by the

Abercrombie went into the game with

the team easily outweighed Hopkins by ten
pounds to the man. Their attack was equally
as heavy as our defense, but our light attack
were like pigmies, compared to the Swarthmore defense.
The game started with a rush, both sides
having the ball and interchanging it by long
throws. In a very short time, however, the
swift, lightning team work and excellent tipping of our men brought the ball with a rush
through the Swarthmore defense to B. Bernheim, who shot the first goal of the game. It
took hardly any time after the change of goals
for the ball to pass again through our attack
to J. Bandel, who, alter a pretty run, made a
fine shot into goal. Hardly ten minutes of
play had elapsed, and the score stood: Hopkins, 2; Swarthmore, o. It was apparent at
once that if our men could only keep up under
the great physical strain, the game would
probably go our way.

Hopkins baseball team opened its schedTHE
ule on Thursday, May 1, by defeating Rock
Hill College in such a manner as to make the
contest almost wholly one-sided. This being
a preliminary game, no wonders were expected, and none were developed. The Hopkins
team made as good showing as could be expected with its late start and small amount of
practice. Baker's pitching was the most noticeable feature of the game. He succeeded in
striking out fifteen of the Rock Hill men,
allowing only one clean hit.
The fielding on our side was rather poor,
but the men ran the bases well, and hit Rock
Hill's pitcher at will, one half of the first
inning being a regular"batting matinee."
The visitors fielded fairly well, making two
pretty double plays, but showed up poorly
with the stick, getting but one hit and three
"scratches."

PURE ATHLETICS.
more does the question of Pure Atho NCE
Athletics present itself to the notice of
the student body. It is positively known that
the University of Maryland entered two ineligible men in the relay races, in which the
Hopkins track team competed, at Philadelphia. The names of these men are Rullman
and Rolph. The former was captain of the
St. John's track team at the time of the games
given under the auspices of the J. H. U., at
the Fifth Regiment armory, and was recently
expelled from St. John's; therefore was disqualified to enter the relay races at Philadelphia, under the regulations which governed
the entries.
The particular regulation referred to, states
that "No one shall represent any college or
university, as a competitor, who has not been
a member of that college or university, in good
and regular standing, from the fifteenth of the
preceding October." Rolph's name is not to be
found either on the attendance list, or the
books of the Treasurer of the University of
Maryland, and if he had been eligible to run
under the conditions stated in above regulation, his name would have been easily found.
As to Rullman, to imagine him captain of the
St. John's track team and, at the same time, a
member of the University of Maryland from
the preceding October, is absurd. Blome was.
also taken to Philadelphia, as a substitute on

9

the University of Maryland track team.
Neither was his name to be found on the attendance list, or the Treasurer's books.
It seems that the ineligibility of these men
was known before they entered the races, but
as the University of Maryland ran so poorly,
finishing last in every relay, it was decided
not to push the protest. It is probably too
late now to enforce the protest, but the facts
of the case should not be passed over, without
being known; therefore THE NEWS-LETTER
takes the present opportunity of publishing
this "breach of good faith" which the University of Maryland has evidently been
guilty of.
Great care has always been taken to keep
athletics at Hopkins on the "dead level," and
it is hoped that all underhand business by
institutions with whom we compete will be
detected and exposed in the future, as it has
been in the past.

NORTHFIELD, 1901.
you see five or six hundred college
WHEN
students gathering and spending ten
days together in the midst of the summer vacation, there are one or two things that you
may safely infer. You may be pretty sure that
when this thing keeps up for fourteen years
there must be a magnet of some kind drawing
hard, that either they or their friends have
been there before and had a good time. Further, you may guess that these men will not
let go this chance to come into close touch
with one another in friendly rivalry and intercourse. The Northfield Conferences are primarily religious gatherings; the men who
come there are for the most part Christian
men; there are a good many meetings of a distinctly religious character, addressed by leading Christian speakers and writers from all
over the world. And in consequence, the principal effect that these Conferences have on a
man is not that on his social nature, nor his
physical make up, nor his brain. A man's
spiritual being is given a stimulus and is deepened in a most unusual way. The large colleges send crowds of men to Northfield every
year; last year Yale had over a hundred delegates. These fellows are the cream of their
institutions, and many a man who has been at
Northfield looks back to it as the starting
point for a life-long friendship of the truest
sort.
This year the management of the Conference has made arrangements with some of the
ablest speakers to address the meetings. President Seth Low of Columbia, Dr. Alexander
Mackenzie of Harvard, Dr. Maltbie D. Babcock, and then Mr. Mott and Mr. Speer, are
to be on hand for the Conference.
Hopkins sent ten men last year, and the
prospects are that during the ten days of the
Conference this summer, from June 27th to
July 8th, we shall have at least 15 at the camp.
Mr. A. R. Bird is chairman of the Northfield
Committee. If you can, go see him at once.
All J. H. U. men will be gladly given a place
on the list. You can't find a place where you
can get so much enjoyment, amid such pleas-

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ant surroundings. so little money, anywhere.
And if you go once, you will never regret that
you made the effort.

H. F. PERKINS.

Mr. Editor:—
I am a Freshman. Have many accomplishments, among them several thousand dollars
left me by a distant relative. Would like to
meet a young widow not over 30, with matrimonial intentions.
CHARLIE.
Call at this office at 4:30 tomorrow afternoon, and if your accomplishments are as you
state, you may be initiated into the Order of
Buffaloes. Then you will be in a fair way to
meet anybody, with any old kind of intentions.
A young and dashing Junior who is about
to get married, wishes to meet a sage old gentleman who can dissuade him from taking the
fatal step. Experience required.
Call at the office of W. B. S. 30 years hence.
Am troubled with insomnia and nervousness
on retiring. Will pay liberal price for efficient
remedy.
We have tried lots of remedies for this malady, and have found the following effective:
Grasp sides of bed firmly, close eyes, elevate
head slightly, body straight, toes turned downward. Now, having dismissed all other
thoughts from the mind, imagine that Dr.
is lecturing on English Literature.
His tones may at first seem harsh and cracked,
but they will soon be modulated until they
flow like tinkling dewdrops on a snow-white
lily in summer, or a pearly mountain stream
trickling down a deep precipice in winter. If
this treatment is kept up faithfully for an hour
each night you will experience "striking"
results. Positively no apparatus required.
Address reward to this office immediately.
Where does the eleven cents that I paid to
join the Buffaloes, go?
Toward the million-dollar endowment which
is now being raised for the University.

ago?

'Am fond of reading. Can you suggest a
late book by a good author?
"Theory of Physics," by J. S. A., can be had
neatly bound, at Cushing's, for a moderate
price. We know you will enjoy it.
Are all the fellows who belong to the Y. M.
C. A. Christian gentlemen?
Yes, drunk or sober.

MARMALADE.
(With apologies to George Ade )

A YOUNG Chap who was not altogether a
Slow One, once sat his Carcass at a
Table, and shoving a Pen lovingly within his
Fist, bethought himself to write some Rhyme.
His Intentions were good ; in fact, they savored of being excellent; he had Nerve,
boosted up by a Backbone of unstaggering
Resolution. And as he contemplated and
meditated by Periods, filling up the Intervals
with soft, rag-time Cusses, a Feeling of Disgust grew upon him,—that is to say, it didn't
ketch Root, but jes growed. So he poked
himself in the Slats and racked his poor dense
Block until he became nervously fidgety.
Finally the theme of Sleep fluttered and did a
coochee-coochee Stunt before the hazy vision
of his Lamps; but before his Bunch of Intellect could cause him to spinach on Sleep, he
was sonorously, soundly snoozing.
Moral: Do not be governed by Hearsay:
for this is an instance where a thing is more
readily done than said or talked about.

"SLEP."

EXAMINATIONS IN THE CELESTIAL
KINGDOM.
BOUT 600 A. D. a Chinese emperor instiAtuted
the first known competitive examina-

•

tions. They were in literary and historical
subjects, and the degrees given enabled their
possesors to enter the civil service. As a result,
to-day the great body of educated men in the
most immense nation on earth are pursuing
classical studies, which lead toward degrees
corresponding to our A. B., Ph. D., etc., conferring the right to go into politics; and these
degrees are obtained by undergoing a course of
tests before which the most fearsome college
examinations seem child's-play.
These great systems of government examinations for literary degrees are most important
to every educated Chinaman. For the degrees
are the only passports to public office; and to
get into politics is the earnest aim and hope of
every literary Chinaman.
This is quite
natural. From an Oriental's point of view,
government positions are most valuable, both
socially and financially. An imperial representative, in any of the nine ranks, enjoys
personal immunity, and belongs to the only
aristocracy of the land, that of education.
Moreover, the tremendous network of provincial government affords unexcelled opportunities for bribery and extortion. It is the
popular opinion that officers of the government
generally squeeze out of their positions about
ten times the lawful salary. Under these
attractive conditions, it is small wonder that
candidates flock by thousands to the towns
where the trials are conducted.

No. 15.

It is not known how many of the applicants
have attended the colleges and high schools.
A large number of them are prepared by tutors.
For all the test is alike; even the National
College at Pekin, the highest institution of
the empire, confers no privileges on its
graduates.
Four successive degrees may be won. The
first signifies "flowering talent," and has been
translated "bachelor of arts." It is conferred
at the provincial capitals. Each province of
the empire is divided into departments, and
these are subdivided into districts. A triple
series of examinations is held; the best men in
each district go up to the chief town of the
department, and the best men in each department proceed to the capital of the province.
To these finals not more than one-tenth of the
first applicants succeed. In 1832, 4000 men
came up for the first trial from twc: districts
aggregating 1,500,000 population. Out of
these 4000 only thirteen in one district, and
fourteen in the other, passed the first series.
A "bachelor" can be a great man in his
native town. He is enrolled among the "gentry," and his social position is assured. He is
exempt from corporal punishment. He can
be a magistrate, or the head man of the village.
And if he wishes to go on, he is eligible for
the next examination.
The second degree, that of "promoted men,"
is bestowed triennially at the 18 provincial
capitals. The examinations are very useful
in weeding out the bachelors and separating
them into "students" and "officers," since
bachelors' degrees are sometimes procured by
bribery and influence.

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The examining hall at Canton will serve as
a specimen. It contains 7500 cells, furnished
simply with two boards, one for sitting, the
other for writing. These cells are arranged
around a number of open courts, so that constant watch may be kept over the students.
This is no idle form. Miniature editions of
the classics and MS. essays are quite often
secreted by the applicants, in spite of the most
careful searching, which extends to each man's
wadded clothes and inkstand, or round lump
of sulphate of iron.
Penalties for this method of cheating the
professor are grotesquely severe, including the
punishment of the offender's father and tutor.
Among the Chinese, indeed, there is absolutely no idea of the "honor system." A
candidate who is caught breaking the rules is
expelled from the examinations, and his name
is "pasted out" on the main door; yet he turns
up again for the next trials with apparently
unimpaired standing.
The students, shut up in these tiny cells,
receive on the first day essay themes from the
Four Chinese Books, on the second day subjects from the Five Classics, and on the last
day
. topics concerning doubtful points of government. The first of these Five Classics
dates back to 1150 B. C. The Four Books are
comparatively modern. They were edited
about moo A. D. These ancient books of
wisdom are the mainstay of all Chinese literature and government. They contain innumerable philosophic sayings, thousands of which
each student must know by heart. For in
this, as in all other examinations, the best man
is he who can write from memory the greatest
number of Confucian maxims, who can most
closely imitate the terse style of the sages, and
who can turn out the largest quantity of polished verse in a given time.
The mental exercise of handling about thirteen such essay themes in three days' time can
be well appreciated by any college Senior.
The Chinese students, moreover, are bothered
by the smoke of the cooking around them,
enervated by the excessive September heat,
cramped and numbed by the long confinement

in their narrow cells, measuring 3x4 feet, in
which there is no room to lie down. They
often become insane; many of them die outright. Especially is this the case with the old
men who flunk year after year, but keep trying.
In sonic instances, father, son, and grandson
have been taking the same examination at the
same time. When an old gray-head succumbs
to the awful strain, his body is shoved through
a hole in the wall, left to the pity of his
friends.
Different is the reception that awaits the
victors—those who live and succeed. There
are sonic 70 or 8o of them, out of 5,000 to
o,000 applicants, in each province. They are
banqueted with great pomp by the governors,
commissioners and high officials; their names
are posted in a public place, while the governor bows, and salutes are fired. Offices are
open to those who wish them. The others are
ready to take the next examination.
The board of examiners, meanwhile, are
having their own troubles. There are ten
men; they are allowed twenty-five days for
their work, and they have to select the 70 or
8o best out of from 50,000 to 75,000 papers on
a dozen subjects. This might average about
260 essays a day for each examiner. The
marking system, too, is closely watched by
the students ; any impartiality or error is
liable to raise a storm of protest, and the examiners must steer carefully to avoid irritating
the graduates. The utmost rigidity, however,
is customary in marking the papers. One
abbreviation of a character has condemned an
essay.
Those "promoted men" who do not at once
take office may try for the third, or "doctor's"
degree. The examinations are held triennially
at Pekin. Each test lets through from 150 to
400 "doctors." The three honor men receive rewards from the Emperor himself; and
offices of all kind, civil and literary, are ready
for those who have passed the third degree.
The fourth and highest distinction is more
an office than a degree; for those who attain
it become members of the Imperial Academy,
and receive salaries. The examination is at

:.:••11111

THE NEWS-LETTER.
the Emperor's palace, before the greatest personages of the empire; and the degree is one
of the highest honors that can be bestowed
upon a Chinaman.
In this manner, beginning with an examination in the little district village, and finally
mounting to the court of the Son of Heaven
himself, a Chinaman of literary ability can
hold the most splendid offices and ranks in the
empire. The system has its faults: it allows
cheating, bribery, impersonations, the forging
of diplomas. But it consistently hammers at
the theory that the man must be fit for the
office. In this respect the Chinese system of
examinations has no parallel in any past or
present government.

A LIKENESS OF PROFESSOR FRANCIS
J. CHILD.
many days ago a medallion likeness of
NOT
Professor Francis J. Child, of Harvard
University, was presented to the Johns Hopkins University by Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
Professor in the Medical School. The likeness
is in bronze, and was modelled by Miss Lelia
M. Usher, of Boston. It is an excellent work
and brings vividly to mind the characteristics
of the man whom it portrays.
The advanced students of English, with
some of the instructors and a few friends,
assembled to review the life of Professor Child
and to bring to mind his various contributions
to the study of English literature and philology.
Three papers were presented by members of
the English Seminary, namely: by R. D. Miller, on the "Life and Character of Professor
Child;" by George D. Brown, on "Professor
Childs Investigations of Chaucer's L a n guage;" by L. Wardlaw Miles, on "Professor
Child's Studies of English and Scottish Ballads."
Professor Green, who had been a pupil of
Professor Child, also gave some personal reminiscences, and other speakers who were present contributed.to the interest of the occasion
by brief remarks.
It is not generally known that at the open-

3

ing of this University Professor Child was
invited to come here as Professor of English.
He was strongly tempted to accept, but certain
changes were made in his relations to Harvard
which lessened his duties there, and he at
length declined the overtures from Baltimore.
Some passages of his letter are still of interest:
"As I told you, a large salary is a consideration that my circumstances will not allow me
to make light of. The liberal plan of your
University presents attractions which are at
least equal to the better salary. You see,
therefore, that I do not find it easy to decline
the honor which you offer me. If you will
take off one half my years and the obligations
to other people which I have incurred in them,'
I will accept your proposition with delight."
When it was found that he could not come
as a permanent professor, he was invited to
come as a lecturer, and this he did for two
successive years. In the first year he lectured
upon Chaucer; in the second, upon "Ballads;"
and he gave a supplementary course of lectures
upon Shakespeare.

AFTER
lacrosse team has met with defeat, but a
defeat of which we have no cause to be
ashamed. Naturally it is a disappointment, a
bitter disappointment, to every son of "old
Tommy Hopkins" to witness such a finale
after the most brilliant lacrosse season we have
ever had, but no fault can be found with our
men for the result. They did their best; no
more could be asked. Swathmore played a
better game, and—won. Starting the season
with men such as McInnes and Maddren out
of the game, the Hopkins lacrosse team
showed how machine-like team work could
be developed, and the result was an attack
which, taken as a unit, has never been surpassed, if equalled here.
Three of the hardest games of the season
within eight days, was a fearful strain on our
men ; but, after it is over, it is useless to speculate upon what the results might have been
if circumstances had been different. "The

Lord loveth whom he chasteneth;" so, after
all, the lesson may not be altogether devoid of
beneficial results. At all events we have a
team to be proud of, and Captain Tyler and
his men are to be congratulated for their season's work.

OW that the Hullabaloo elections are over,
and an editorial staff representative of the
class of 1902 has been chosen to edit next
year's book, it is only fair to say that while
these men will doubtless exert every effort to
make their publication a success, a great deal
of this success depends upon the rest of the
class. It must be borne in mind that the
Hullabaloo is not a creation of some dozen men
who have been honored by being chosen to
edit it, but a product of the entire class. Remember, every Junior is an integral part of
the class of 1902, and next year's Hullabaloo
is the official publication of that class, in which
every member should feel a vital interest.
This interest will be made much stronger by a
contribution of your talent to the book. Bear
this in mind during the coming vacation, and
devote some of your spare moments to writing
something for your class book. During the
next scholastic year, be on the alert for interesting items that will help to swell its pages.
If the interest of each member of the class can
be sufficiently aroused for them to take this
small amount of trouble, THE NEWS-LETTER
predicts that next year's Hullabaloo will be the
best ever published at the University.

COLUMBIA, 1.

Saturday, May 4th, Captain Tyler's men
ONscored
another victory and added to their
belts the scalps of the men from Columbia.
Both teams played a very creditable game, and
the New Yorkers were beaten only by the
superior team work and faster stick work of
the Hopkins men. Owing to a severe injury
to his foot, Putts was unable to play at his
usual position, which was filled by StrausStraus has always played on the defense,
where his wonderful coolness stands him in
good stead; but he did well in his new position
and put up a clean heady game.
For the most part, the work was done by
the attack, which put up a fair game, although
the passing at times was very ragged; and only
once did the defense have half a show, and that
at the time when the visitors scored their only
point.
The stars of the game were Hatch and
Bandel. Hatch's playing was steady and
thoroughly reliable. He accepted every opportunity and shot three of the seven goals;
Bandel also distinguished himself by shooting
three goals from a very difficult position.
Sayler signaled his return to the game by
clever work at third defense.
Both teams started off with a rush. After
the face-off Straus got the ball and tried for a
goal, but failed. Hatch then got the ball and
shot for the post. It looked like a goal, but
proved not to be, and the ball was soon down
the field again. On his next attempt Hatch
was more successful and scored the first point
for Hopkins. Columbia was the next to score.
Bigelow got the ball and passed to Stewart.
Stewart tipped to Major who placed the ball in
the net. From this time on the Hopkins
attack bombarded their opponent's goal, which
in the end netted them seven points.
The defense did the best work for the Blue
and White. Lindsay, the goal tend, was
applauded warmly, and the work of O'Dwyer,

Colwell and Schwerin in their struggle to keep
the ball out of the net was notable. The body
checking of the New Yorkers was frequent
and well done.

HARVARD, 0.

ON Monday, May 6th, the best game of
lacrosse seen here this season resulted in a
victory of our boys over the visitors from
"fair Harvard" by a score of 4 too. Up to
her defeat here, the record of the Crimson has
been a brilliant one, and the success of the
Hopkins men in white-washing them was a
most gratifying surprise. Both teams put up
an excellent game, and the representatives of
the Black and Blue fairly outdid themselves.
In all points Hopkins outclassed Harvard, and
her success is well merited. Hopkins' team
work was splendid, and time after time the ball
came rapidly up the field. Each man on the
attack tipped with such a precision as to cause
the crowd to stand in open-mouthed astonishment.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
Inside of two minutes after the referee's
whistle sounded the first goals had been scored
by our boys, and before another two minutes
passed a second tally was added. Much of the
credit for this fast scoring is due to the
Hopkins coaches and Captain. Tyler. After a
most careful study of the past games with
Harvard it was decided that Hopkins must
"get in the game" from the start. So they
did, and the two goals were the reward of this
timely advice. Before the half had ended the
boys in Black and Blue had put the ball two
more times in the net and had a good lead in
the men from Cambridge. The Crimson defense was good; their attack was better, as our
boys learned in the second half; but by clever
work Briscoe turned aside several shotA which
seemed good, with the result that Harvard
had to be content with not scoring.
The play of Wynne, Howards "Canuck"
at Cover Point and Guggenheimer, Hopkins
old goal tend was quite noticeable, and drew
frequent applause from the thousand people
who eagerly watched every play from the
grand stand.

for the ball to pass again through our attack

play had elapsed, and the score stood: Hopkins, 2; Swarthmore, o. It was apparent at
once that if our men could only keep up under
the great physical strain, the game would
probably go our way.

Hopkins baseball team opened its schedTHE
ule on Thursday, May 1, by defeating Rock
Hill College in such a manner as to make the
contest almost wholly one-sided. This being
a preliminary game, no wonders were expected, and none were developed. The Hopkins
team made as good showing as could be expected with its late start and small amount of
practice. Baker's pitching was the most noticeable feature of the game. He succeeded in
striking out fifteen of the Rock Hill men,
allowing only one clean hit.
The fielding on our side was rather poor,
but the men ran the bases well, and hit Rock
Hill's pitcher at will, one half of the first
inning being a regular"batting matinee."
The visitors fielded fairly well, making two
pretty double plays, but showed up poorly
with the stick, getting but one hit and three
"scratches."

PURE ATHLETICS.
more does the question of Pure Atho NCE
Athletics present itself to the notice of
the student body. It is positively known that
the University of Maryland entered two ineligible men in the relay races, in which the
Hopkins track team competed, at Philadelphia. The names of these men are Rullman
and Rolph. The former was captain of the
St. John's track team at the time of the games
given under the auspices of the J. H. U., at
the Fifth Regiment armory, and was recently
expelled from St. John's; therefore was disqualified to enter the relay races at Philadelphia, under the regulations which governed
the entries.
The particular regulation referred to, states
that "No one shall represent any college or
university, as a competitor, who has not been
a member of that college or university, in good
and regular standing, from the fifteenth of the
preceding October." Rolph's name is not to be
found either on the attendance list, or the
books of the Treasurer of the University of
Maryland, and if he had been eligible to run
under the conditions stated in above regulation, his name would have been easily found.
As to Rullman, to imagine him captain of the
St. John's track team and, at the same time, a
member of the University of Maryland from
the preceding October, is absurd. Blome was.
also taken to Philadelphia, as a substitute on

9

the University of Maryland track team.
Neither was his name to be found on the attendance list, or the Treasurer's books.
It seems that the ineligibility of these men
was known before they entered the races, but
as the University of Maryland ran so poorly,
finishing last in every relay, it was decided
not to push the protest. It is probably too
late now to enforce the protest, but the facts
of the case should not be passed over, without
being known; therefore THE NEWS-LETTER
takes the present opportunity of publishing
this "breach of good faith" which the University of Maryland has evidently been
guilty of.
Great care has always been taken to keep
athletics at Hopkins on the "dead level," and
it is hoped that all underhand business by
institutions with whom we compete will be
detected and exposed in the future, as it has
been in the past.

NORTHFIELD, 1901.
you see five or six hundred college
WHEN
students gathering and spending ten
days together in the midst of the summer vacation, there are one or two things that you
may safely infer. You may be pretty sure that
when this thing keeps up for fourteen years
there must be a magnet of some kind drawing
hard, that either they or their friends have
been there before and had a good time. Further, you may guess that these men will not
let go this chance to come into close touch
with one another in friendly rivalry and intercourse. The Northfield Conferences are primarily religious gatherings; the men who
come there are for the most part Christian
men; there are a good many meetings of a distinctly religious character, addressed by leading Christian speakers and writers from all
over the world. And in consequence, the principal effect that these Conferences have on a
man is not that on his social nature, nor his
physical make up, nor his brain. A man's
spiritual being is given a stimulus and is deepened in a most unusual way. The large colleges send crowds of men to Northfield every
year; last year Yale had over a hundred delegates. These fellows are the cream of their
institutions, and many a man who has been at
Northfield looks back to it as the starting
point for a life-long friendship of the truest
sort.
This year the management of the Conference has made arrangements with some of the
ablest speakers to address the meetings. President Seth Low of Columbia, Dr. Alexander
Mackenzie of Harvard, Dr. Maltbie D. Babcock, and then Mr. Mott and Mr. Speer, are
to be on hand for the Conference.
Hopkins sent ten men last year, and the
prospects are that during the ten days of the
Conference this summer, from June 27th to
July 8th, we shall have at least 15 at the camp.
Mr. A. R. Bird is chairman of the Northfield
Committee. If you can, go see him at once.
All J. H. U. men will be gladly given a place
on the list. You can't find a place where you
can get so much enjoyment, amid such pleas-

THE NEWS-LETTER.
ant surroundings. so little money, anywhere.
And if you go once, you will never regret that
you made the effort.

H. F. PERKINS.

Mr. Editor:—
I am a Freshman. Have many accomplishments, among them several thousand dollars
left me by a distant relative. Would like to
meet a young widow not over 30, with matrimonial intentions.
CHARLIE.
Call at this office at 4:30 tomorrow afternoon, and if your accomplishments are as you
state, you may be initiated into the Order of
Buffaloes. Then you will be in a fair way to
meet anybody, with any old kind of intentions.
A young and dashing Junior who is about
to get married, wishes to meet a sage old gentleman who can dissuade him from taking the
fatal step. Experience required.
Call at the office of W. B. S. 30 years hence.
Am troubled with insomnia and nervousness
on retiring. Will pay liberal price for efficient
remedy.
We have tried lots of remedies for this malady, and have found the following effective:
Grasp sides of bed firmly, close eyes, elevate
head slightly, body straight, toes turned downward. Now, having dismissed all other
thoughts from the mind, imagine that Dr.
is lecturing on English Literature.
His tones may at first seem harsh and cracked,
but they will soon be modulated until they
flow like tinkling dewdrops on a snow-white
lily in summer, or a pearly mountain stream
trickling down a deep precipice in winter. If
this treatment is kept up faithfully for an hour
each night you will experience "striking"
results. Positively no apparatus required.
Address reward to this office immediately.
Where does the eleven cents that I paid to
join the Buffaloes, go?
Toward the million-dollar endowment which
is now being raised for the University.

price. We know you will enjoy it.

MARMALADE.
(With apologies to George Ade )

A YOUNG Chap who was not altogether a
Slow One, once sat his Carcass at a
Table, and shoving a Pen lovingly within his
Fist, bethought himself to write some Rhyme.
His Intentions were good ; in fact, they savored of being excellent; he had Nerve,
boosted up by a Backbone of unstaggering
Resolution. And as he contemplated and
meditated by Periods, filling up the Intervals
with soft, rag-time Cusses, a Feeling of Disgust grew upon him,—that is to say, it didn't
ketch Root, but jes growed. So he poked
himself in the Slats and racked his poor dense
Block until he became nervously fidgety.
Finally the theme of Sleep fluttered and did a
coochee-coochee Stunt before the hazy vision
of his Lamps; but before his Bunch of Intellect could cause him to spinach on Sleep, he
was sonorously, soundly snoozing.
Moral: Do not be governed by Hearsay:
for this is an instance where a thing is more
readily done than said or talked about.

"SLEP."

November 7th, 1900.
While visiting the Paris Exposition of 1900, the wonderful display of
wines from all parts of the world was made a special study by our representative, who secured some very fine cuvees of French wines, both
red and white, such as Chateau Pontet Canet, Chateau Larose, Chateau Lafitte, Chateau Margauft, Clarets; Sauternes, Haut Sauternes,
and Chateau Coutet. The latter finer than Chateau Yquem and not so
sweet. Also some special vintages of Deinhard & Co.'s celebrated Rhine
Wines selected while visiting their great wine vaults at Coblenz on the
Rhine. The most valuable selection of all was the prize Oporto Port,
the finest of all Wiley Forrester & Co.'s exhibit; a very old, strictly
pure, rich, medicinal Port wine, which will be shipped in 120 gallon
pipes direct from the Exposition ground to
